channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #157 - Barcelona or London?
item.description:
Hi,

I am back from my vacation in Barcelona and the news in the Perl world is that there is going to be a Perl workshop in Barcelona, and on the very same day London will also hold its annual Perl Workshop. Look for the details at the end of the newsletter!

In other news Neil Bowers is busy preparing all of us for 'CPAN-day' coming up in 2 weeks. - See the articles below.

Enjoy! ~szabgab
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Writing private functions in Perl
item.description: Neil Bowers explains several ways to make functions 'private'. Some are by convention (prefixing the name with an underscore), others are experimental (lexical sub), yet others require additional modules from CPAN (Sub::Private). You have a choice how private do you want the functions to be.

item.title: Calculating Probability
item.description: Article published on Linux Magazine by Mike Schilli. (most of the article is for paying readers only)

item.title: Testing with Perl
item.description: A collection of Perl Maven articles and screencasts about testing using Perl.

item.title: The Unicode section of our style guide
item.description: Learn how does Lokku/Nestoria handle Unicode in Perl. Without much theory, just the useful bits.

item.title: Formats
item.description: I remember when I first started to teach Perl using a slide-deck provided by the training company. It taught all kinds of thing people hardly used. Including format. It is probably not very useful today, but if you are interested, brian d foy has just published the part of the 'Learning Perl' book that covered this feature of perl.

item.title: Perlweekly Confidential: Corralling News
item.description: Yanick shares his new toy, how he gathers news items from RSS feeds to build the Perl Weekly on the weeks when he is the editor.

item.title: (?P<NAME>...) vs (?<NAME>...)
item.description: Steven Haryanto explains how to make your named captures (in regexes) more similar in Perl and Python by using the 'P' prefix.

item.title: Dezi::App
item.description: Dezi is a search engine platform based on Swish3, Apache Lucy, OpenSearch and Plack. Peter Karman has just finished porting it to Moose.

item.title: Easily add tab completion feature to your CLI program using Getopt::Long::Complete
item.description: Steven Haryanto has a new module on CPAN.

item.title: The ghost of CPAN Days past
item.description: CPAN day is on 14th August. Last week Neil Bowers urged us to do something special. This time he tell us what happened on that very special day in every one of the last 19 years.

item.title: Give your modules a good abstract
item.description: Neil Bowers helps us make our modules more findable by people. In a separate article he also suggests how to write good synopsis for our modules to make it easier to get started.

item.title: Let's top git.io
item.description: Mark Keating, the marketing manager of the Perl Foundation, is calling you to follow Kent Fredric on GitHub in order to give Perl developers a better representation in the git.io/top list.

item.title: Past few weeks with MetaCPAN.
item.description: Talina Shrotriya provides update on her GSOC grant - 'Starring of Modules' and 'Web of Trust'.

item.title: Github, Travis-CI and Perl
item.description: Dave Cross talked at the technical meeting of the London Perl Mongers.

item.title: Performance Profiling with Devel::NYTProf
item.description: Tim Bunce explains the various views you can generated using the profiler he maintenance, and then provides lots of suggestions how to improve the speed of your code. (50 min presentation from YAPC::NA)

item.title: Perl-related events
item.description: In the following cities: Sofia (Bulgaria), Tokyo (Japan), FlÃ¶rli Olten (Switzerland), Hancock (NY/USA), Itapema (SC/Brasil), Salzburg (Austria), Barcelona (Spain), London (UK)
